parameters.jsCode: return [{ json: { output: "Sample chat response to avoid gas fees during testing. Had this been an actual response, you would likely have been treated to an overly enthusiastic response, and a follow up question that would make Captain Obvious blush. If you need a long response, say 'long'. For a complex response containing code blocks and lists, say 'html'." } }];

here is a simple "Hello World" example using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript

HTML:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Hello World</title>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
<body>
    <h1 id="greeting"></h1>
    <script src="script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

CSS (styles.css):

body {
    display: flex;
    justify-content: center;
    align-items: center;
    height: 100vh;
    background-color: #f0f0f0;
}

h1 {
    color: #333;
}

JavaScript (script.js):

document.getElementById('greeting').textContent = 'Hello, World!';

Here is a sample ordered list

  1. Mercury
  2. Venus
  3. Earth
  4. Mars
  5. Jupiter
  6. Saturn
  7. Uranus
  8. Neptune

Here is a sample unordered list

  • Cesium-131: Used in brachytherapy for treating some types of cancer.
  • Cesium-133: The only stable and naturally occurring isotope of cesium.
  • Cesium-134: A radioactive isotope used in some medical and industrial applications.
  • Cesium-135: A long-lived radioactive isotope found in nuclear waste.
  • Cesium-137: A radioactive isotope produced from nuclear fission, used for medical and industrial applications.
